displayed_text: Patient: I stopped doing that quite a while ago. Family Member 1: Yeah, that's what he said about a couple of weeks ago. He stopped. He's giving her separated. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, now, M_____'s pregnant, she picked up his water and drank the whole water the other day by accident. I don't know. Doctor: That's okay. Yeah, I think where when you're on chemo, you have to use universal precautions, you know. So it's always easier if you have more than one bathroom in your home. So that even if you have your own bathroom space where your towels and you can have Lysol and things. You feel comfortable. That's just his bathroom, so that you don't always constantly have to Lysol and Clorox things. Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right.

Patient: I couldn’t do it. got tired at looking at those big pills. I said you wait until I see my doctor. I’m gonna tell her she’s making me take these… Doctor: No but don’t stop them. Patient: Oh no, uh-uh, uh-uh. Doctor: Keep going with them. Patient: I got a certain time I take every day with them too. Patient: I take them at uh, at uh, what time I take them? I take them at ten fifteen every night. Doctor: You have different times for everything. Patient: I try to keep a time when I take medication because if you don’t let it go three or four hours before then, to me it’s just – if you take at the right time… Doctor: As long as you know what time you’re taking what, that’s good enough. Patient: Oh yeah, oh yeah. ten fifteen every night. Doctor: Okay. Alright I’ll see you back next month. Healthcare Professional: Yep.

Patient: Nope. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay. And we talked last time about whether you want a call from the quit line to help you quit. The answer’s no because you just told me you don’t want to quit. Patient: No. That’s the least of my trouble. I ain’t going to do it. Doctor: I tell you ever you and I have the same birthday? Patient: Yeah. (Laughs) Doctor: So comes in for follow-up. How have you been? Patient: Well, besides that, huh, that pain I’m still getting. Except for now I’m getting a pain right here. I’m thinking this is from this. I’m not sure. But, huh- Doctor: So where’s the pain at that you had before? Patient: Down in here. Doctor: In your buttock? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Or it’s hips and buttock?

Family Member: He took him off of that. Patient: I was ready to say that. Doctor: Your Colace or the docusate to help soften your stools? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Folic acid one milligram pill a day? Patient: Yes. Doctor: The gabapentin three hundred milligrams three times a day? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. So lidocaine patch. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Patches twice a day? Once a day? Patient: Maybe twice a day.

Patient: Yeah, I know that. Yeah, Yeah. Doctor: So. Um. You know, my sense is that it is research because we’ve got a new drug added to it. You know, looking forward to having the conversation about what options might be still important. Um. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um. Um. (Pause5sec) Patient: So, why don’t we try to, to, to have the blood taken and, and, see if, if what that brings back, but maybe a a - in lieu of that possibly being negative, um, look at the other clinical trial. Doctor: So, I’ll go print out, uh, do you want me to just not print out the chemo one? Patient: Yeah. Yeah, I guess. Doctor: So, I’ll print out the phase one and I’ll print out the immune therapy one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, those are two sort of, uh, things that you can be taking home and reading. Patient: Right. Doctor: I would stay with the current treatment for now.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, that’s our plan. So, going forward, you’re going to have to see me much more frequently than before. Patient: That’s fine. I like you. I would not mind seeing you more frequently. Doctor: Thank goodness. Doctor: hhh Now, that is something. Even though, I yell at you sometimes. Patient: Right. Noooo, I’ve got, Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’ve got a lot of respect for you. Doctor: Thank you. Sit up for a minute. Let me, uh, put down. (Paper rattling) Patient: Mmm.hmmm.

Patient: No, no. I, I came here because Dr. T___ out at S__ say, say, oh, you know, certainly recommended it. I guess he’s part of this study too, so. Doctor: He is. He is. Patient: So uh he felt pretty strongly that coming here to participate but also to, to say here is- Doctor: Remind me again how you hooked up with him. Patient: Yeah. Through the urologist that I had that did the surgery. Doctor: Because you’re mostly east coast. You, you moved? Patient: Yeah. We lived in C___ for twenty one years. Doctor: That’s right. That’s right. Patient: We, we were out there. Doctor: That’s right. Patient: Everything was there, except summertime. Doctor: I remember. You moved to uh-

Family Member: Everybody’s like taking pictures. (Laughter) Patient: Yeah. She took some good pictures with our camera. I ain’t lying. She took some good pictures. Doctor: And so do you have to drive like far from where you’re staying to get to the park? Is that why you have to get up so early? Family Member: Well they, because the animals is up early. Patient: No. Doctor: No. But I mean you’re not like driving three hours to get there? Patient: No. Family Member: No. Patient: No. Uh-uh. No. We, we had to drive that far to get there, but- Doctor: Did you stay like in a hotel or where did you stay at? Family Member: It was in a hotel. Then they get the bus to pick up at the hotel, then it takes you to the, uh, park, and then you get in this- Patient: You get in those little trucks.

Family Member: It’s between Johannesburg and on the Cape Peninsula area. Because that’s what they were telling us. Ya’ll need to put your feet in the Indian. Doctor: Oh. The Indian Ocean? Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Oh, yeah, that’s right, the Indian Ocean. Family Member: Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: The Indian Ocean comes over to that. That’s wild. Family Member: Right. (Laughter) Patient: Oh, yeah. That was a deep, deep, deep, deep experience. Doctor: Well, I’m glad it all went well for you. Family Member: Yeah. It was nice. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: All right. We’ll get you moving.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Okay? Patient: Alright. Doctor: Alright. Patient: No problem. Doctor: But, I cannot be putting you on medications and then leaving you with whatever you’re dealing with. Okay. Just like that. Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Because I know you’ll never call me if you’re getting sick from the medicine. Patient: Oh! I’ll call! Doctor: No, you won’t! Patient: Yeah. I’ll call. Well, like I said, I started getting that pain in my hip last week, but I knew I was coming here today to see you, and I said I’ll just wait until I go in. But, yeah, it was getting kind of, it was startin’ to hurt. Doctor: Getting tough.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, based on your interpretation, perhaps they’re a little bit better. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not putting words in your mouth. Uh, so before I came in to see you today, I was kind of planning to say like this doesn’t look like it has been working that well, maybe we should switch to something else. After speaking to you, and hearing it from you, I’m kind of backtracking a little bit and I’m beginning to think like maybe we should give this a chance to work a bit longer. Um, you certainly haven’t had like the best possible response that we could have expected. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We have seen patients who, even in the first two months, their PSA level drops by fifty percent, and the tumors begin to shrink. We certainly haven’t seen that. On the other hand, we haven’t seen like an obvious, uh, progression of the cancer either on the scans. So I would say, you know, you’re certainly not the best case scenario on this medication, but you’re by no means the worse, either, somewhere in the middle, and so that’s why I needed some input from you as far as what you think we should do. I’m willing to stick with this a little bit longer. We don’t want to wait too long so that, you know, if something bad happens like one of your bones fractures or pain gets excruciatingly worse, uh, and so, and on the other end of the spectrum as well, your anemia is still there, so your hemoglobin level was still below nine. It was about eight point nine, uh, on the most recent check, and even if we decided to continue on this study at the very least between now and your next visit- is that September fourth? Family Member: Fifth. Doctor: Fifth? We would need to, again, hold the drug. Because even at the lower dose of two-fifty, it’s still causing, you know, that significant anemia. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, uh, I just want to get a sense from you whether you think you might, you know, want to stick with this for about two more months until the next set of scans? Whether you feel that you’ve had enough and you want to try something new? Or like where are you at with this? Patient: Well- Family Member: So, can I give you my perspective-? Doctor: Yeah. Please. Yes.

Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: Well, I think I’m dandy. The question is are you dandy? Family Member: Right. We haven’t got the blood work back yet, so. Doctor: Yeah. PSA’s not back. The rest of you is actually okay. Family Member: He was going through, he went through a rough time after radiation. You probably talked to the other doctor. I mean he was on his hands and knees with his head on the couch. And I went, J___, you need to go up and get in bed. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: He was pretty bad. Patient: I was just checking. Doctor: What is it? Patient: I was just checking. Family Member: Do you have any- Doctor: That is like, I’m going to shoot you. I’ll be right back. Okay boss. Patient: I was just checking.

Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you-

Family Member 1: Yes, super hormones uh for what duration? Doctor: We, uh I give them for three months for four doses of chemo three weeks apart. Family Member 1: And let me ask you um, Are there any treatments that you use with the PSMA that targeted those cells, um? Doctor: Um yes, so, so, you’re talking about like PSMA radionuclide therapy and um right now there are a couple of clinical trials in the United States for guys who have failed hormone therapy. There are also – um you can do that – I’ve sent probably; uh I’ve sent twelve guys over to Germany to get that therapy in the last eighteen months uh you know specifically to try and like avoid like hormone therapy or something. What I can tell you is in this setting that therapy is not curing anybody. So if you’d asked me eighteen months ago, I would have said sure, let’s send you over there. What I’ve learned in the last eighteen months is that nobody I’ve sent over has been cured by that therapy, and uh I don’t consider it worthwhile right now. Family Member 1: Okay, and then the other question was - I don’t know if this makes a difference or not, Do we have a Gleason score of the margins that were left? Doctor: So it’s and uh irrelevant and undoable because you know the therapy he received, uh we wouldn’t uh it’s not scored. Family Member 1: I see. Doctor: So it’s, But it’s irrelevant. The cancer’s out. It’s an aggressive cancer. Family Member 1: Um Hmm. Patient: What are the side effects from the chemo and super hormones? Doctor: Yeah, uh so the biggest side effect, quite frankly, so let’s talk about hormones first. Uh because the super hormones don’t add anything. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Mmm Doctor: wanna do anything, you don’t, you know if there’s anything that sort of Patient: No. And, and with the kind of work that I do, it’s not unusual to get in at two or three in the morning, have to get up at six in the morning, and you just, you have to drive on. You sleep for three hours in the afternoon, and then you go to work at six at night and work until eleven. And then, it, it just is part of what I do. Um, so. Doctor: Okay. And, uh, last time we talked - Family Member: So, as a, a young man he worked the night shifts- Patient: Oh, yeah. Family Member: So he had Patient: For eight years. Family Member: Weird sleep rhythms then. And then he, he did, um, move into a period of time where he worked a more normal, more universal schedule. Yeah and then started this, you know, this investigation thing which is very, sometimes it’s very haphazard. Doctor: Okay. Well, last time you were talking about kidney stone pain and that you felt like you were peeing razor blades. Patient: Yes, none. That had happened, maybe two more pees. (Laughs) Doctor: And, have you been to the hospital?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.strongly disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.::: strongly disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian
